content.body: I'm exploring ways of "properly" or "ideally" marking up ASCII art, and there seems to be very few existing discussions of the topic.
WCAG 1.0 has some techniques: http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG10-HTML-TECHS/#ascii-art
the "skip over " links always seem like a hack
anyone have any data on what ATs do with <pre> marked up ASCII art?
wonders if anyone considered making a MIME type for ASCII art, e.g. image/ascii
text/art
there is this test case (for supposedly accessibly marked up ASCII art) http://www.bentoweb.org/ts/XHTML1_TestSuite3/testfiles/sc1.1.1_l1_038.html
linked from http://www.bentoweb.org/ts/XHTML1_TestSuite2/metadata/sc1.1.1_l1_038
hober I was thinking text/art as well, until I realized that text is merely the stream format, not the general type of thing
image/text would be more accurate than text/image
woah, xmlns has no definition of an XML namespace-well-formed internal general parsed entity
bummer
tantek: what would be the right way to provide accessibility for ASCII art?
text equivalent?
<pre> would be right layout-wise but I don't think it has an obvious way to provide a text equivalent, other than ARIA
othermaciej - yes, a *visible* text equivalent/alt/explanation is what WCAG suggests
I would like a way to say <pre art>
visible - sounds good
(not an actual proposal)
just to illustrate the concept
I don't want ATs to attempt to speak/pronounce the ASCII art
it really does appear that there's no way to use namespaces with internal general parsed entities
if the goal is to just stop AT from reading it, then <pre role=presentation> would do it
how the heck do i define the XML serialisation of a DocumentFragment then
what's an internal general parsed entity?
is that a fancypants way to say document fragment?
othermaciej - ok I'll look at role=presentation. thanks.
it a fancypants way of referring to the kind of stuff you'd find inside an element in XML
i.e. the string forming the text, comments, other elements, etc in an element
would it be sufficient to define it by saying if you surround the fragment with an element, that must produce a namespace-well-formed document?
yeah that's what i'm doing
but that's a hack

For the purposes of this section, an internal general parsed entity is considered XML namespace-well-formed if a document consisting of an element whose contents are the internal general parsed entity would itself be XML namespace-well-formed.
perhaps you should specify that the hypothetical element does not itself have any namespace declarations
yeah

For the purposes of this section, an internal general parsed entity is considered XML namespace-well-formed if a document consisting of an element with no namespace declarations whose contents are the internal general parsed entity would itself be XML namespace-well-formed.
Hixie - how can anyone expect web authors to understand something like that?
web authors aren't expected to even see that
it's in a class="impl" section
so it would be hidden from the author view
ah ok, thanks.
even if Microsoft doesn't contribute anything to HTML5, it's still really valuable for them to *say* they're contributing
for the record, Jena having six or so URL-like things is a spec problem: URI, IRI, XLink, XML system ID, etc.
why do things like XLink and XML System ID have their own syntax?
hsivonen: ^
(curious)
othermaciej: they tried to anticipate IRIs when IRIs weren't ready, so they defined their own ways of turning a Unicode string into something you can give to an ASCII-only URI resolver
I see
fun
as for XML Schema anyURI, IIRC, they didn't get it right the first time
and not the second time
and the third attempt turned out to be permissive enough to allow any string
resource identifiers are so simple compared to stuff like HTML and HTTP, I wonder why we have all these divergent slightly different specs
I can think of 2 reasons
1) People wanted to mark some cases as erroneous instead of making all possible strings resource identifiers
2) The identifiers weren't Unicode from the beginning
I guess in the very beginning it wasn't clear that unicode was the answer
nick
test
resists the urge to say that RDFa isn't so much a cow path as a bunch of people pointing through a marsh and saying "let's go that way"
that's not quite resisting
but nice try
Damn, foiled again

Regardless of cowpathiness, the principle just says "When a practice is already widespread among authors, consider adopting it rather than forbidding it or inventing something new.", and RDFa was indeed considered (and rejected)
and the whole Design Principles document doesn't become useless just because one principle in one situation did not override all other considerations
Stop trying to counter my desire to construct grandisoe metaphors involing waders by pointing out that simple fact based arguments are more effective

Rather than a bunch of people pointing through a marsh, perhaps the bunch of people has carefully navigated a complex path safely through the marsh, and then said "come on over here", and the hordes rush towards them in a straight line and sink, and then the bunch of people say "what's the problem? ignore the sinking hordes, we got here fine"
that's quite a good metaphor
jgraham: (I'm not sure I agree that facts are more effective than metaphors)
can't work out whether RDFa is meant to be defined in terms of syntax (which Shane seems to say) or in terms of a tree model (which Manu seems to say)
how can i disallow the user from bolding or making new lines in a contentEditable element?
hachque, by using scripting in one way or another
isn't sure what the best way would be for this particular issue
If I specify a type on a link - does the browser set the Accept header accordingly?
<a type="application/pdf" href="/document">
is that part of the HTML5 spec?
No
unless I'm horribly mistaken
Is there any reason that could not be ammended in the spec?
because that is how the type attribute works for style elements
here we go again...
I'm not asking for a new attribute I'm asking to ammend the existing attribute
hsivonen, yeah...
mookid: Yes
yes?
It would break pages that currently use <a type> and also do browser sniffing based on Accept headers
those pages would presumably not upgrade to HTML5
and if they did they would test before they transitioned?
Pages don't have a choice, because browsers aren't willing to implement separate modes for HTML4 and HTML5
All pages get processed according to HTML5's processing rules
what's the point in the  document definition jibberish then?
if that is the case, I'm pretty sure any change you make will break something somewhere
In HTML5, the only point is to make browsers go into standards mode instead of quirks mode
ok so that could be incorporated into quirks mode?
Things will break, but we want to minimise that, by not making changes that we know will break things
ok..
Lots of current pages render in standards mode (and lots in quirks mode), and HTML5 browsers ought to be compatible with all of them
Also, quirks are evil and we don't want more of them
s/evil/expensive/
lol..
clutching at straws here a bit eh?
so can someone please explain why style and script tags use the type attribute to set the accept header
but not in link elements
and where in the spec that is specified
didn't think they did set the Accept header
firefox does
unless firebug lies
Hixie: you want to clear that up for me?
please

not especially, but i would suggest testing the difference between <script src="x">, <script src="x" type="text/javascript">, and <script src="x" type="application/ecmascript"> and seeing if the type="" attribute really has any effect
well either way it is pretty clear that the Accept header should change depending on the semantics of the hyperlink
Accept is a hold-over from a pie-in-the-sky idea that never panned out and which should be dropped altogether
as it stands there is no way of linking to a specific representation if the URI leverages (HTTP compliant) conneg
Hixie: that is your opinion
indeed
did it ever occur to you
that might be because the hypermedia we have in circulation
doesn't provide the mechanism to leverage it
it's not because you can't leverage it, it's because it's useless
maybe we should just ignore PUT DELETE and OPTIONS aswell
nobody uses those 'in practice' either?
oh no wait
if you have different resources, just name them different things
you're added them
that makes perfect sense.
Hixie: they aren't different resources
that is your opinion
yes it is.
did it ever occur to you
which is why an optional type attribute would do nobody any damage
and me a lot of good
that since they aren't the same resource, they might in fact deserve different names?
and anyone else who's actually read and understood the HTTP spec
(i.e. not you)
mookid: Please
yeah ok i'm kinda tired of you insulting me
so this conversation is over
yeah ok well you repeat yourself and ignore what I'm saying to you
stop coming here every other week asking for this feature
what do you expect?
it's not going to happen
we have a process for adding new features: http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/FAQ#Is_there_a_process_for_adding_new_features_to_a_specification.3F
and no part of that process involves you insulting people on IRC
I suggest insulting people on blogs instead
ignoring people and not listening to them is rude
I don't think you understand the significance of the term 'resource' or 'representation'
they are important terms
so when you tell me two representations are two resources
If you were being ignored, you wouldn't have generated so much conversation on IRC
and argue based on that (wrong) assumption
You're just being disagreed with, which is a different issue
it's kind of galling Ian.
I'm not being ignored because deep down you know I'm right
:P
this is Ian's subjective opinion that URIs are Uniform Representation Identifiers
and HTTP conneg is 'useless'

mookid: You have ignored the fact that everyone else disagrees with you. You have ignored the fact that you are using the wrong procedure to ask for what you want. And you seem to have ignored the life leson that insulting people doesn't make them more sympathetic to your cause
ok so the majority of people don't understand what a resource is
not many people read specs properly
that doesn't make me wrong

It seems kind of like you're fixated on some specific HTTP syntax, and saying that it's impossible to implement the REST architecture without it, but that seems unrelated because there's not a 1:1 mapping between HTTP and REST anyway, so you can just implement the architecture with different syntax
jgraham: But insulting people can be funny
I really didn't say anything that bad
I guess that's why mpilgrim's blog is popular
get a grip. :/
this is crazy - I can implement a prefectly valid HTTP resource with multiple representations but you won't provide the mechanism to use it properly
on the basis that you don't think that part of HTTP should be there
and 'quirks are evil'
it's not even like this change actually causes any issues for 'your way'
even if the accept header changes - why does it matter if you aren't doing HTTP conneg?
it doesn't.
infact, it'll reduce the length of the header, make the HTTP message smaller - and save some trees
maaaaaaan.

(Hmm, even http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_3_2_7 doesn't seem to like Accept much - "In short, a server is rarely able to make effective use of preemptive negotiation")
the main barrier to that is lack of effective hypermedia
I don't think HTTP messages are made out of trees, unless you're using a very outdated protocol
no but HTTP messages are routed and processed
if they're smaller less energy will be used to transmit them
that's irrelevant anyway - it's not an incompatible change, you have quirks mode incase some muppet is doing something super weird with the accept header
the *only* reason I've been given so far is Ian's opinion that HTTP coneg is 'wrong' and 'doesnt work'
which he justifies by clearly misinterpreting the meaning of the term 'resource'

It takes like a microsecond for a router to process a hundred bytes of HTTP header, and if you have a trillion HTTP requests per day then that's only 10 days of processing time, so it's like 10 computers dedicated to processing the extra header for the entire world
which isn't much
that wasn't a serious point.
It's more interesting than serious points, though
yeah well
don't think there's any doubt about that here
wonders how many HTTP requests per day there are in the world
"resources are made of cheese - you're argument is invalid"
oh ok thanks Ian
Protector of Internet Citizens from the evils of HTTP Application develoeprs
I think I'll file a bug report in the spec where you're adding PUT/DELETE to the method attribute - it's not used in practice so it's broken
when is it being added?
why^

Hmm, http://www.thepicky.com/software/google-handles-235-million-searches-per-day/ says Google only has hundreds of millions of searches per day, which is billions of requests, and I suppose it's reasonable to imagine people do hundreds or thousands of requests before searching again
http://bitworking.org/projects/atom/draft-ietf-atompub-protocol-09.html#accept
Philip`, mandatory data retention laws may solve this question as soon as a sizable set leaks
I finally got approval for TPAC. :-)
I'll be attending
yay
erlehmann: Okay, I'll watch the torrent sites for a file with a petabyte of leaked daily internet traffic
i mean, i'm sorry for you that you'll be there, but i'm glad for me that you'll be there :-P
Philip`, data retention is only connections, not content, so …
haha :-D
Hixie: I apologise if I offended you by inferring you didn't understand the HTTP spec. Do you want to first have a discussion on wha tthe meaning of 'resource' is?
I didn't intend to offend you btw, I just assumed that was a correct accusation given your interpretation of 'resource'
erlehmann: That won't help answer my question then, if it doesn't keep enough content to identify HTTP requests :-(
(including in keepalive sessions)
i have not read the data retention specs, so i'm afraid i cannot answer that
Maybe I could just ask the internet to use my computer as a proxy for a day, so I can measure the traffic accurately
I hereby pronounce tomorrow, the 23.09.2009 the first annuary Philip Taylor Proxy Day \o/
The cabal sure can help you with that, Philip` ;)
Hixie: has an "unselectable" attribute been considered for inclusion in HTML5?
no
not as far as i recall
erlehmann: Excellent!
hsivonen, unse-what ? you mean not being able to get focus?
erlehmann: I'll tell you my IP address tomorrow (it's dynamic so I'm not sure what it'll be)
erlehmann: I gather it's an IE thing for restricting contenteditable and/or designmode
I'm pretty sure if there was a floor in my reasoning you wouldn't hesitate to point it out :)
snickers with glee
Hixie: "The HTML syntax does not support namespace declarations, even in foreign elements" - doesn't it support xmlns:xlink in foreign elements?
which counts as (partial) support for namespace declarations
Philip`: it supports creating a namespace declaration but it doesn't support making the declaration affect processing in the parser
plus plain xmlns in foreign elements, which is also a namespace declaration
so the cause and effect are reversed compared to XML
hsivonen: That sounds like it still supports (some) namespace declarations, it just doesn't support the use of declared namespaces
Philip`: indeed
three declarations to be exact
Hixie, this bug isn't fixed, despite you marking it resolved http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7506
Philip`: it doesn't support namespace declarations in any meanginful sense

Hixie, I wanted you to update the spec where it says "The presence of an obsolete permitted DOCTYPE." in the implementation requirements of section 12.1.1 Warnings for obsolete but conforming features.
oh, in the implementation section
I suggest it be ammended to say something like "The presence of an obsolete permitted DOCTYPE. (HTML only)"
ok, doing that now
sorry i thought you meant the previous section
is there going to be an API for doing javascript includes?
so you can have a one line script tag that boostraps a page
http://www.spicywebdesign.com/first-html-example-page-html-5-code/
heh
Creap, wat
I wonder how you'd come to the conclusion that you can make up your own elements
so I just read up on the RDFa discussion and was a bit surprised that we're still not passed xmlns being in a namespace in XML and not in HTML not being considered any kind of issue phase
hah, bug 7594's section is #_firebugConsole
Hixie: The syntax supports (some) namespace declarations in as meaningful a way as XML does, by parsing them into the same DOM
i guess
how would you phrase it?
The key difference is that HTML doesn't support arbitary namespace declarations
I guess
That's like asking me for constructive comments, which is not fair
But I don't really know which bit of the spec you are talking about
Hixie, you're making too many checkins! I barely have enough time to reload and review the changes before the notification pops up telling me to do it again.
hehe
Hixie: I might just phrase it exactly like how it's phrased now, and tell people to not be pointlessly pedantic about it
works for me!
well, we're back to e-mails being the highest line, so i guess tomorrow i'll return to bashing on them
nn
we need a higher resolution graph to actually see the details of recent months :)
on http://www.whatwg.org/issues/data.html that is
annevk2: Use Safari and increase your desktop scaling factor and then it'll be higher resolution :-)
annevk2: doesn't http://www.whatwg.org/issues/data.html?period=1 work?
zcorpan: cool. thanks
the whole point of vector graphics in defeated when one zooms the page in Firefox
D;
(yes, I realize it's not really vector graphics)
thinks the graph should be in SVG
zcorpan, ah, the feature is already present
hsivonen, or Firefox should get a better zooming algo
annevk2: a better zooming algo doesn't help here
annevk2: either all canvases should have a hires backing buffer in case the user zooms
annevk2: or there should be a way to asks the page to repaint canvas to a new hires backing buffer after zooming
Or you should use SVG if you want scalable vector graphics
do we have a non-game use case for <canvas> yet that shouldn't have been addressed by using a non-<canvas> solution?
hello everyone
hello
it seems Hixie has beaten the high score on revision activity last week
is there any user agent which implements <style scoped>?
hsivonen: Maybe the Paint clone
v.nu implements it i think
and things that apply custom JS filters to images/videos
though maybe it's not the kind if user agent you're looking for :)
zcorpan: indeed
i don't think any browser has implemented it
i am thinking more along the lines of gecko, webkit, presto or even trident
zcorpan: do you know if there are plans for it? like in dev builds of gecko/webkit/etc
don't know
oky, thanks anyway ;)
if you want it, file bugs
hm, not really sure if it fits the use-case scenario i want it for
notes that http://www.whatwg.org/issues/data.html is invalid after scripts have run
Hixie: am I allowed to comment on that bug?
mookid, yes. Anyone is allowed to
heyho everybody
does anyone know a html5 parser written in c that is reusable?
ideally one that can emit errors and warnings and as such used for validation
err
how do you determine if a bug is resolved or not
I didn't even get a chance to respond to that and it's already closed..
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7697
mitsuhiko, there's no standalone c implementation yet
annevk2: is anyone working on that?
and are there estimations about how complex that would be?
there's hubbub, but I'm not sure how up-to-date it is
mitsuhiko: I'm working on a C++ implementation that is Gecko-specific
basically i would love to see a live-html5 validator for firefox
there is a sgml validator already, but that one of course does not do the trick with html5 :)
mitsuhiko, did you look into Validator.nu?
annevk2: that is quite complex to setup and requires java as far as i know
how do you guys decide whether or not an issue in the bug tracking system should be closed or not?
and sending http requests there for everything does not sound like a good idea
i'm already using validator.nu as part of my testsuite though
mitsuhiko: I plan to add parse error reporting eventually, but adding error reporting is at the bottom of the priority list, because it isn't needed for parity with the old parser
hsivonen: makes sense
the bugzilla entry is https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=512229
also that stuff is localization-sensitive and so forth
mitsuhiko, yeah, though hsivonen wrote a To-Mozilla-C translator of some sorts
hsivonen: i will monitor that
mitsuhiko, and the idea is to use that new parser in Gecko in due course
isn't that one already in the nightlies?
at least there is a setting to enable a html5 parser
mitsuhiko: yes
guess i looked at that one yesterday then
mitsuhiko: the ground work of making tokenizer error reporting Gecko-friendly has been done but doesn't have Java-to-C++ translations support yet
unfortunately mozilla code still makes my eyes bleed. i don't understand that com stuff at all :(
mitsuhiko: the ground work for tree builder error reporting isn't done
yeah. saw that
it's not doing anything with errors currently
the sgml validator extension for firefox was the only way i could keep the pages validated, because i just don't have the time to submit all pages to an external validator website
You could have an extension that automatically submits them to an external site and gives you the result almost immediately - would that be adequate?
mitsuhiko: having just an HTML5 parser doesn't give you validation
hsivonen: yes, but it's a good start for writing a validator
Philip`: would require a network connection and would slow down the whole thing a lot
mitsuhiko: I suggest using http://code.google.com/p/jsrelaxngvalidator/ with the schemas Validator.nu uses and porting the rest over using GWT
http://groups.google.com/group/openweb-group is the openweb.org thing I mentioned a while back
found the reference again in his email
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2009Sep/0056.html
What's going on there?

Dashiva: Given that it says "shaped regions for text", maybe the idea is that authors really think it's important to write pages with text wrapped inside a triangle that is morphing into a balloon over time in synchronisation with a video
starts noble attempt to clean up <basefont> mess further: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=518110 & https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=29641
annevk2: why?
Mornin', all.  (Day 11 of no internet at home ;_;)
(If it's bad enough to make commas fall out of your eyes, surely it'd be worth finding some alternative access mechanism :-) )
Still not worth it.  I'm absolutely certain that the day I buy a cellular dongle they will repair the line.
if that's within 30 days of buying the dongle, you can return the dongle, no?
Not if I've opened it.
I think you can return it even if you've opened it, but meh
omg so many emails.  This is the real tragedy of not having home internet - I don't get to clear my inbox every few hours.
Indeed, missing out on days of public-html mail is a tragedy comparable in scope to Hamlet
zcorpan, because it bugs me?
future generations blaming us for not cleaning up enough of the mess of our elders haunts me :)
They're much more likely to blame us for the new messes we're creating
and in those cases there's nobody to shift the blame to
does html5 allow empty <ul>/<ol> tags?
yes
Philip`, those are harder to fix for us because we do not have the benefit of hindsight
annevk2: Experience suggests that won't stop them blaming us for it
so it's even more important to try to fix them :-)
why are light dimmers noisy?
that's something that bugs me
hmm, why can't we use data: urls for workers
Do data urls have an origin?
zcorpan: They've got to do something with the photons that are not coming out of the light, so the dimmers have a little pool of black ink for the spare photons to fall into, which causes the noise
Philip`: still, the noise bugs me and i'd like it if someone invented a silent dimmer
Maybe they should make a dimmer that controls two lightbulbs in opposition, so one is bright while the other is dark
and then there wouldn't be the problem with the spare photons
(Is it the dimmer itself that's noisy, or the bulb?)
TabAtkins: yeah, they do
zcorpan: Interesting.  Is it the originating page?  Everything I know about data urls I learned from wikipedia.
Philip`: the dimmer
zcorpan: Okay - not sure what would actually cause that
TabAtkins: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/origin-0.html#origin-0
doesn't think he's ever experienced that problem himself
Philip`: i've had several dimmers and all of them have been noisy
zcorpan: Ah, so the origin is just a guid, if I'm reading correctly.  Makes sense.
TabAtkins: yeah
but i don't want to have to use another file for workers
maybe i can put the script in a comment at the top of the html and use new Worker('')
Is workers a separate spec now?
is trying to find it.
always been
whatwg.org/ww
Man, I'm all kinds of behind.  I've been keeping up with workers, but only in an abstract sense - I don't expect to be using them for a while still.
Oh, so it's what I thought - the restriction on data: workers is indeed origin-based.
yes
Ok, so now I'm caught up to your question.  ^_^
I'd like a data: worker too.  While the origin is officially different, in practice it should have the same level of trust as the page itself.
yeah
or maybe...
<script type=text/x-worker id=worker>...</script> <script>var w = new Worker('#worker')</script>
Interesting.
Can you do an importScripts with a data url?
isn't sure that would be useful.
If data URLs have a unique origin, does that mean ctx.drawImage(Image with src = canvas.toDataURL()) should now mark the canvas as tainted?
doesn't remember what data URL origins were defined to be when he last checked this, and concluded that it shouldn't taint the canvas
Philip`: no
Philip`: origin for images and documents special-case data:
Oh, okay
Hey cabal: a repeat question and a[nother] stupid question.
1: is there a friendly explanationn of the new content types anywhere (am not relishing trying to write one for html5doctor)
2: got an example of svg in html5 that works and is valid? I want to reassure some people that you haven't killed SVG
Do you mean all new content-types defined/used by HTML5, or just text/html vs application/xhtml+xml?
Philip had an email asking for explanation of flow, interactive, embedded etc
brucel: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/svg-and-mathml-in-html.html has SVG in text/html, and if the validator says it's invalid then hsivonen should fix something
brucel: Oh, I thought you meant HTTP content-types
rather than what HTML5 seemingly calls content models
Does http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/images/content-venn.svg not make it trivially obvious?
Clearly content models are like an amoeba
brucel: (Any SVG in application/xhtml+xml should be just as valid as it always has been)
Philip, well, of course it's trivially obvious to *me* (ahem...)
Philip, but SVG in an html5 doc , served as text/html
brucel: Validator.nu says SVG-in-text/html is invalid in order to discourage authors from using it before browsers are ready.
brucel: yes, it would be better to have a message that says so instead of having a message that says SVG isn't allowed
brucel: (and also, it's spec-wise proper for a validator to say it's invalid if the validator developer opted not to invoke the "other relevant specifications" clause for SVG)
hsivonen wasn't gonna nag you; am simply looking for an example of how to do it. Do I just take my conforming SVG (without doctype) and put it into an html5 page?
brucel: as it stands, you also need to zap the foreign-namespace cruft from Inkscape or Illustrator (which is totally inconvenient)
brucel: and zap Illustrator-emitted namespace-URIs-as-entities
You can always put the SVG in an <object> if you want
which is probably the best approach unless you have a good reason for wanting it to be inline
Ta all. Not sure I'm any the wiser about an html5 doc with svg inside it, tho
Hmm, I think html5lib might have broken pyRdfa
because it seems pyRdfa no longer recognises xmlns:* attributes
because html5lib passes it xmlnsU0003A attributes instead
With what treebuilder?
shrugs
parser = html5lib.HTMLParser(tree=treebuilders.getTreeBuilder("dom"))
does html5lib apply the coercion rules by default?
IIRC no
In DOM I think it does
For some reason
Possibly because of gsnedders
minidom b0rkedness, I bet
claims innocence

Me? None, I;m not running the tests right now

I could just run the parser tests if that would help
Man, why do people keep letting Reschke derail technical conversations with arguments about process?

The test <body><frame></frame></frame><frameset><frame><frameset><frame></frameset><noframes></frameset><noframes> I remember thinking had a bug
Do you have a moment to check?
Not really

?_?  So you can run the first query, possibly alter the list, then run the second query.

OK html5lib testcase: <body><frame></frame></frame><frameset><frame><frameset><frame></frameset><noframes></frameset><noframes>
There is an explicit <body> tag so in after-head mode we set the frameset-ok flag to not ok
Then we switch to in-body and ignore all the <frame></frame> junk
Then when we hit the <frameset> tag frameset-ok is still not OK
So we ignore the token
The first token that is inserted is that corressponding to the noframes element
and the final tree should be
<html>
<head>
<body>
<noframes>
"</frameset><noframes>"

sicking: The nice thing about itemfor's directionality is precisely that the Microdata parent doesn't need to know about its children explicitly, which matches the model when they are DOM children as well.

It seems RDFa proponents are focusing mostly on the important but obvious and thus uninteresting aspects, like whether

in text/html should work (which it obviously should)
while some other people are focusing on the less important but more complex aspects, like precisely defining handling of unobvious edge cases

so it's not helpful when proponents keep pointing out that the simple obvious cases work, because obviously they do, and we're interested in the weird crazy things because that's where the spec is broken
(and that's where there's little interoperability in current implementations)
i have to believe there's a bit of "it's hard to get a man to understand something when his paycheck depends on not understanding it" going on here
(with apologies to upton sinclair, who was talking about something far more important)
Philip`: yes, but how do you explain their reaction to evidence that there is little interoperability in the implementations they cite?
their reaction to google's not-really-RDFa implementation was "that's not a validator"
mpilgrim: Also, it only happens in edge cases, they don't matter in the real world
I'm just skimming the convos, but that didn't make any sense to me.  Of course it's not a validator.  No one's claiming it is.  They're claiming it's not a *consumer*.

In the past there was explicit agreement that RDFa ought to precisely specify the output triples for any input (regardless of validity), so that doesn't seem contentious, so I don't know why there seems to be so much pushback against actually specifying it clearly
At least, not a consumer that anyone can rely on to consume the RDFa that they put into their pages, following the spec as closely as possible.
dashiva: right, they haven't yet internalized that the entire world is just a massive collection of edge cases

(Google's RDFa thing has even more serious problems, like thinking HTML with

...

is two nested elements)
Philip`: Well, RDFa works on source level text, what is there to expect?
like hixie's and hsivonen's explanation to that i18n dude that, for the purposes of the character encoding detection algorithm, the entire web was a legacy environment
